title: 103_s2476
content: The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. Spousal IRA contribution limits are based on the combined compensation of both spouses. The limitation is the lesser of $2,000 or the total compensation of the individual and their spouse for the taxable year. The Act allows homemakers to qualify for a full IRA deduction based on combined spousal compensation. If an individual files a joint return and has less compensation than their spouse, they are eligible for the deduction. The Act allows homemakers to qualify for a full IRA deduction based on combined spousal compensation. Conforming amendments were made to sections 219(f) and 408(d)(5), with changes to contribution limits. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free to buy first homes, pay for higher education or long-term care, or by the long-term unemployed. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free for first home purchases, educational expenses, or long-term care. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions are defined as payments or distributions used within 60 days for a first home purchase, educational expenses, or long-term care, without exceeding the total expenses for the taxable year. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions must be used within 60 days for acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, including settlement, financing, or closing costs. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions must be used within 60 days for acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, including settlement, financing, or closing costs. The term 'first-time homebuyer' is defined as an individual who had no ownership interest in a principal residence in the 3-year period before acquiring the current residence. The term 'principal residence' in the context of qualified first-time homebuyer distributions has the same meaning as in section 1034. The term 'date of acquisition' refers to the date of a binding contract to acquire the principal residence. The distribution from an individual retirement plan can be contributed back if there is a delay in acquiring or constructing a principal residence, as long as it meets certain requirements. The distribution from an individual retirement plan can be contributed back for qualified higher education expenses, with certain conditions. Qualified higher education expenses for enrollment or attendance at an eligible educational institution are eligible for tax benefits, with coordination with savings bond provisions. Qualified long-term care expenses are also considered for tax purposes. Qualified long-term care expenses refer to amounts paid for necessary diagnostic, preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitative, and maintenance services, including insurance coverage for such services. Personal care services are required by functionally impaired individuals to assist with activities of daily living, provided under a prescribed plan of care by a licensed health care practitioner. The term 'functionally impaired individual' refers to someone certified by a licensed health care practitioner as unable to perform daily activities without substantial assistance from another individual. The term 'functionally impaired individual' requires assistance with at least 3 activities of daily living, or 2 if receiving home health care services. The term 'functionally impaired individual' requires assistance with at least 3 activities of daily living, or 2 if receiving home health care services. Activities of daily living include eating, transferring, toileting, dressing, and bathing. A licensed health care practitioner is defined as a healthcare professional with a license. The term 'licensed health care practitioner' is defined as a physician, registered professional nurse, qualified community care case manager, or any individual meeting requirements set by the Secretary after consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term 'qualified community care case manager' refers to an individual or entity experienced in providing case management services, assessing functional and cognitive impairments, and preparing individual care plans, not related to the individual receiving services. The term 'relative' in this context refers to an individual who is not related to the person receiving case management services, as defined in section 152(a). Additionally, there are requirements set by the Secretary in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Penalty-free distributions for unemployed individuals are also addressed in this section. Individuals who have received unemployment compensation for 12 consecutive weeks can now make penalty-free distributions from their individual retirement plans after separation from employment. This amendment allows for distributions during the taxable year in which the compensation is received or the following year. Additionally, section 401(k)(2)(B)(i) is amended to remove certain provisions. Section 401(k)(2)(B)(i) and 403(b)(11) are amended to allow penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses. Amendments allow penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses under sections 401(k)(2)(B)(i) and 403(b)(11). Effective date applies to payments and distributions after the enactment of the Act.
